text: All I've ever done is just try to protect this family and
the whole time, you were just protecting your own ego.
I've sacrificed everything, my career, my body,
everything, just to make you happy.
I mean, what am I to you? A maid, a secretary, a cook?
As the story begins,
we find Joy
at this transition point.
The first part of life is now closing.
Raising kids, running this business,
she and her husband are retiring.
But what is next?
To our kids, now I get to make up for lost time.
And Brooke and Gina, guess who's available
full time to help with the wedding?
Joy Delaney ran a
forty year marathon.
Forty years of a marriage and of raising children.
And at the end, nobody thanked her.
Then something breaks.
Joy disappears.
It's a truly riveting and also a really harrowing mystery.
Joy Delaney, mother of four, has gone missing.
There's a kind of lie that we've all been told as women,
which is that running the show
and putting out the fires—
She's a cheater, dad.
Cheater! That's good, coming from you.
Stop! Stop! Stop!
—that's considered a job women just do.
Every night, just like clockwork,
Stan says, "Joy, what's for dinner?"
I mean, why is that my job?
There's a lot of deep issues that we're getting into.
Like the complexity of love. The contradictions in love.
That a woman, a mother,
can love her children, love her husband—
Let's keep doing this thing.
Whoo!
Cheers!
—and also resent where she is in life.
I think as people, we always hold
these contradictions within ourselves.
Joy definitely has contradictions going on.
And a lot of it is under the surface.
I have some news.
You and Gina set a date!
Oh Jesus Christ, Joy.
What's that saying? Family knows how to
press your buttons cause they installed them.
I love that!
We're telling a really honest story
about what it is to experience the decades of your life.
What I hope is that people feel
that they see something
of themselves in what we're doing.
I want people to feel seen when they see this.
That they can look at the really
complex moments in our show and say, "Oh my god,
I feel that way too. This show gets it!
They're telling the truth."
